text: For the first several years, it was doubling, 10-xing every year. Taping user counts that we printed out to the wall, and then running out of space on the wall. Having to put 100,000 users, 200,000, 500,000, 1,000,000, 10,000,000 on the ceiling.
speaker: Drew Houston
context: Lenny asks Drew about the early days of Dropbox when things were going extremely well. Drew is describing the incredible growth Dropbox experienced in its first era from 2007 to around 2014. He explains how they would physically print out user milestones and tape them to their office wall to celebrate their rapid user growth, eventually running out of wall space and having to put the numbers on the ceiling as they hit millions of users.
text_ko: 처음 몇 년 동안은 매년 두 배가 되기도 하고, 어떤 해는 10배씩(10-xing) 늘었어요. 사용자 수를 출력해서 테이프로 벽에 붙여 놨는데, 이젠 벽에 붙일 자리가 없어서 10만명, 20만명, 50만명, 100만명, 1,000만명 같은 숫자들은 결국 천장에 붙여야 했어요.
text_zh: 头几年真是疯狂，每年都翻倍，甚至涨十倍。我们把打印出来的用户数贴在墙上，后来墙都贴不下了。10万用户、20万、50万、100万、1000万，最后只能贴到天花板上去了。
text_es: Durante los primeros años, se duplicaba, se multiplicaba por 10 cada año. Pegábamos en la pared las cifras de usuarios que imprimíamos, y después ya no cabían más en la pared. Tuvimos que poner los números en el techo: 100,000 usuarios, 200,000, 500,000, 1,000,000, 10,000,000.

text: But weirdly, it was sort of like you see the videos where there's the mushroom cloud in the distance. You see it. But you don't hear, or notice it. It was also clear that winter was coming.
speaker: Drew Houston
context: Drew is explaining how major tech companies like Apple, Microsoft, and Google started launching competing products around 2011-2012. He uses a vivid metaphor comparing their competitive threats to seeing a distant nuclear explosion - you can see the mushroom cloud but don't immediately feel the impact. The phrase 'winter was coming' refers to Drew sensing that difficult times lay ahead for Dropbox despite not seeing immediate effects in their user numbers.
text_ko: 이상하게도, 마치 멀리서 버섯구름이 피어오르는 영상을 보는 것 같았어요. 눈에는 보이는데 소리는 들리지 않고, 별로 실감이 나지 않았어요. 그리고 겨울이 다가오고 있다는 것도 분명했어요.
text_zh: 但很奇怪的是，就像你看那些视频里远处的蘑菇云一样。你能看到，但听不见，也感觉不到什么。而且很明显，寒冬就要来了。
text_es: Pero qué raro, era como cuando ves esos videos donde hay una explosión nuclear a lo lejos. La ves ahí. Pero no escuchas nada, ni te das cuenta del impacto. También estaba clarísimo que se venían tiempos difíciles.

text: Less than a year later, Google Photos launches. And not only does it provide a lot of the same value, but they also gave you free unlimited storage for life. And so, they just totally nuked our business model.
speaker: Drew Houston
context: Drew is describing a pivotal moment in 2015 when Google launched Google Photos with free unlimited storage, directly competing with Dropbox's Carousel photo-sharing product. This was devastating because Google could afford to give away what Dropbox was trying to monetize. Drew uses strong language to emphasize how completely this undermined their strategy - Google didn't just compete, they 'totally nuked' Dropbox's ability to charge for photo storage.
text_ko: 1년도 채 안 돼서 구글 포토가 나왔어요. 우리가 제공하던 핵심 가치를 많이 그대로 제공했을 뿐만 아니라 평생 무료 무제한 저장공간(unlimited storage)까지 제공했어요. 그래서 그들이 우리 비즈니스 모델을 완전히 무너뜨려 버렸어요.
text_zh: 不到一年，Google Photos就上线了。它不仅提供了差不多同样的价值，还给用户终身免费无限存储。这样一来，我们的商业模式就被彻底干掉了。
text_es: Menos de un año después, Google Photos sale al mercado. Y no solo ofrecía prácticamente el mismo valor, sino que además te daban almacenamiento ilimitado gratis de por vida. O sea, nos volaron completamente el modelo de negocio.

text: So it killed Carousel, killed Mailbox, went all-in on productivity. And I wish I could say, 'Then, everything got better.' It was the opposite, actually. The narrative completely flipped on the company. Suddenly, your employees don't want to wear your T-shirt anymore.
speaker: Drew Houston
context: Drew is explaining his difficult strategic decision in 2015 to shut down Dropbox's photo-sharing app Carousel and email client Mailbox to focus entirely on workplace productivity tools. Instead of solving their problems, this pivot made things worse - the company's reputation declined dramatically, employee morale plummeted, and even workers became embarrassed to be associated with the Dropbox brand, symbolized by not wanting to wear company merchandise.
text_ko: 그래서 Carousel 서비스를 접고 Mailbox도 중단하고 생산성에 올인(all-in)했어요. 그리고 ‘그다음에 모든 게 좋아졌어요’라고 말하고 싶지만, 사실은 정반대였어요. 회사에 대한 이야기가 완전히 뒤집혔고, 갑자기 직원들이 더 이상 회사 티셔츠를 입고 싶어 하지 않아요.
text_zh: 所以我们砍掉了Carousel，砍掉了Mailbox，全力押注生产力工具。我多希望能说'然后一切都好起来了'，但实际上恰恰相反。公司的形象完全翻车了。突然间，你的员工都不愿意穿你们公司的T恤了。
text_es: Así que liquidaron Carousel, liquidaron Mailbox, y se volcaron completamente en productividad. Y ojalá pudiera decir 'Y entonces, todo mejoró.' Pero fue todo lo contrario. La narrativa de la empresa cambió por completo. De repente, tus empleados ya no quieren ni ponerse la camiseta de la empresa.

text: But I'm very busy, but I'm not really productive. I'm not putting in a lot of creative input. Then the company's not getting a lot of creative output. It just seems like lose, lose, lose all around.
speaker: Drew Houston
context: Drew is reflecting on a fundamental problem he identified with modern work culture after COVID. He describes being trapped in a cycle where he was constantly busy with meetings and emails but wasn't actually being productive or creative. This realization led to Dropbox's new mission of designing 'a more enlightened way of working' because Drew recognized that being busy doesn't equal being effective, and this was hurting both individuals and companies.
text_ko: 근데 저는 너무 바쁜데 정작 생산성은 높지 않아요. 창의적인 투입(creative input)을 많이 하지 못하고, 그러다 보니 회사도 창의적인 산출(creative output)을 많이 얻지 못해요. 결국 모두에게 손해 보는 상황이에요.
text_zh: 但是我特别忙，可实际上效率很低。我也没有什么创意投入(creative input)。这样公司也得不到什么创意产出(creative output)。感觉就是各方面都在输，没有赢家。
text_es: Pero ando súper ocupado, pero realmente no estoy siendo productivo. No estoy aportando mucha creatividad. Entonces la empresa tampoco está obteniendo resultados creativos. Se ve como que todos perdemos por todos lados.

text: You end up fighting wars on three or four fronts against the big kahunas that have infinite cash, and can do whatever they want.
speaker: Drew Houston
context: Drew is describing the strategic challenge Dropbox faced when trying to compete in multiple product areas simultaneously - file storage, photo sharing, productivity tools, and enterprise solutions. Each area put them in direct competition with tech giants like Google, Apple, Microsoft, and Meta. These companies had vastly superior resources and could afford to operate at losses or give away products for free to eliminate competition, making Dropbox's multi-front strategy extremely difficult to sustain.
text_ko: 결국엔 자금이 무제한인 거물(big kahunas)들과 세네 군데 전선에서 싸우게 돼요. 그들은 돈이 많아서 하고 싶은 건 다 해버리거든요.
text_zh: 到头来你得同时跟三四个大佬打仗，人家钱多得花不完，想怎么搞就怎么搞。
text_es: Terminas peleando en tres o cuatro frentes contra los peces gordos que tienen dinero ilimitado y pueden hacer lo que se les dé la gana.
